content:
• Tuesday, June 14, 2016
  • GDDY

    GoDaddy drops after filing to let investors sell shares

    • GoDaddy (NYSE:GDDY) has filed to allow investors owning 4.2M shares (over 2.5% of outstanding shares) to sell on the open market.
    • Shares are down 4.3% after hours to $31.34.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:49 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: CS +7.8%. OTC:DWTI +3.4%. AGM +4.8%. JUNO +4.4%. DRIP +2.9%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: TAX-OLD -2.7%. SYF -2.6%. WLL -2.6%. SDRL -1.5%. UCO -2.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM | 8 Comments
  • SALT

    Scorpio Bulkers to launch 20M-share offering

    • Scorpio Bulkers (NYSE:SALT) -7.4% AH after announcing a public offering on 20M common shares, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 3M shares.
    • SALT says it plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:24 PM | 17 Comments
  • REXX

    Rex Energy to sell Illinois Basin assets for ~$40M

    • Rex Energy (NASDAQ:REXX) +7.2% AH after agreeing to sell its Illinois Basin assets to Campbell Development for ~$40M, with the potential for up to another $10M over three years based on commodity prices.
    • The sale includes 76K net acres in Illinois, Indiana and Kentucky, with current production of ~1,700 net bbl/day.
    • Rex says it plans to use the proceeds to pay down its revolving line of credit and for general corporate purposes, and expects to maintain its current $190M borrowing base.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:43 PM | 4 Comments
  • HCLP

    Hi-Crush Partners to launch 3M-unit offering

    • Hi-Crush Partners (NYSE:HCLP) -7.3% AH after announcing a public offering of 3M common units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 450K units.
    • HCLP says it plans to use the proceeds for general partnership purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM | 7 Comments
  • TWTR

    Twitter invests $70M in SoundCloud; shares keep rallying after Microsoft/LinkedIn deal

    • Two years after Re/code reported Twitter (TWTR +5.6%) is thinking of buying music/audio-sharing platform SoundCloud, it has reportedly invested $70M in the Berlin-based company.
    • The investment is said to be part of funding round expected to total ~$100M and involve a ~$700M valuation, similar to what SoundCloud was valued at in a 2014 round. Jack Dorsey has confirmed Twitter invested in SoundCloud this year "to help support some of our efforts with creators," but didn't share financial details. SoundCloud, in some ways a social media platform as much as a music service, claims to reach ~175M monthly active listeners
    • Twitter is up 9.6% over the last two days, as Microsoft's $26.2B deal to buy LinkedIn fuels hopes Twitter will also get acquired (and has perhaps sparked some short-covering). The NYT observes brain drain fears caused by a depressed stock price may have motivated LinkedIn to sell. Twitter appears to be facing a similar challenge.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 33 Comments
  • BAC

    Financials slide along with interest rates

    • The S&P 500 is down just 0.25%, but the financial sector (XLF -1.5%) is taking a far larger beating as the idea of higher interest rates fades, with German 10-year yields falling below zero, and the U.S. 10-year Treasury yield within sight of its all-time low. KBE -2.3%, KRE -2.3%
    • The FOMC concludes its two-day policy meeting tomorrow, at which updated economic projections and dots will be unveiled, along with a Janet Yellen press conference.
    • How much of the panic into fixed-income is due to concern about the U.K. exiting the EU will become evident next Thursday night as that country's Brexit votes are tallied.
    • Bank of America (BAC -2.5%), Citigroup (C -3.1%), Wells Fargo (WFC -2.5%), Regions Financial (RF -2.9%), KeyCorp (KEY -3.7%), PNC Financial (PNC -2.4%), Fifth Third (FITB -2.6%), SunTrust (STI -2.8%), E*Trade (ETFC -2.6%), MetLife (MET -1.6%), Prudential (PRU -1.8%), BNY Mellon (BK -2%)
    • ETFs: XLF, FAS, FAZ, UYG, VFH, IYF, BTO, IYG, FNCL, SEF, FXO, RYF, FINU, RWW, XLFS, FINZ, JHMF, FAZZ, FNCF
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 89 Comments
  • AAL

    Ugly day takes some airline names down to 52-week lows

    • A number of airline stocks are at or very close to 52-week lows as a combination of factors continue to drive selling pressure.
    • The Orlando terror attack and anxiety over the impact of Britain leaving the European Union on business travel top the list.
    • American Airlines (AAL -4.9%), JetBlue (JBLU -3.2%),  and United Continental (UAL -4.8%) slumped to one-year lows.
    • Spirit Airlines (SAVE -3.8%), Alaska Air Group (ALK -4.5%), Delta Air Lines DAL, Hawaiian Holdings (HA -3.3%), and  Southwest Airlines (LUV -5.3%) are also down sharply.
    • The U.S. Global Jets ETF (NYSEARCA:JETS) has nowhere to hide and is down 3.17%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM | 71 Comments
  • MFRM

    Mattress Firm still a short says SA contributor

    • "Don't fall for management's assurances that things are getting better and get sucked into this value trap," says Illuminati Investments, who earlier this profitably named Mattress Firm (NASDAQ:MFRM) as his top pick to short in 2016 (it's off about 30% since).
    • Reading through the conference call (transcript), Illuminati notes management's litany of excuses and refusal to recognize they may have just rolled up a bad business model.
    • The "eye-popping" loss was thanks to the writing off of the goodwill of brand names being consolidated under one banner. What's particularly concerning is management's admission that the Sleepy's locations would be converted first since they had nearly five years of deferred maintenance on them. "So what exactly did they get for almost $1B?"
    • Previously: Rebranding costs whack the bottom line at Mattress Firm (June 10)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:24 PM | 4 Comments
  • MPAA

    Motorcar Parts of America rallies after guidance satisfies

    • Motorcar Parts of America (MPAA +8.5%) pops over the $30 level for the first time this month after releasing FQ4 results.
    • During the company's conference call, management guided for FY17 sales of $420M to $440M vs. $433.2 consensus. An adjusted gross margin rate of between 27.5% to 30.5% is expected.
    • MPAA earnings call transcript
    • Previously: Motorcar Parts of America misses by $0.04, misses on revenue (June 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:19 PM | 1 Comment

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: RKDA +12%. SGY +10%. WG +7%. PARR +6%.
    • Losers: PQ -13%. WGP -11%. PFIE -10%. UAN -10%. CRC -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM
  • BR

    Broadridge to buy DST's North American customer communications business

    • Broadridge Financial (BR +1.8%) announced earlier that it agreed to acquire the North American customer communications business from DST Systems (DST +0.4%) for $410M.
    • The NACC business - the largest transactional printer in North America - generated $1.1B in revenue for Kansas City-based DST, or ~40% of the company's annual revenue.
    • BR expects the deal to be immediately accretive to earnings, and expects to achieve ~$20M in annualized cost synergies within 18-30 months of closing.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:24 PM
  • CGNX

    Cognex drops on a Canaccord downgrade to Hold

    • "While we continue to expect CGNX to benefit from growing deployment of machine vision in factory automation and logistics, we do not see catalysts for substantial upside to our estimates for the remainder of 2016," writes Canaccord's Bobby Burleson, downgrading Cognex (CGNX -4.5%) to Hold. His target remains at $45.
    • Burleson: "With valuation near historical peaks, the stock is likely to be range bound the balance of the year. Signs of meaningful traction in mobile terminals (new product released last quarter), combined with a more diversified base of large orders, especially for consumer electronics, could make us more constructive on 2017 estimates and prompt us to revisit our rating."
    • The industrial machine vision hardware provider is still up 24% YTD. Shares go for 28x a 2017 EPS consensus of $1.48.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:07 PM

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: CARV +7%. UVE +5%. OTCPK:FSAM +5%.
    • Losers: SYF -13%. TREE -10%. OMF -8%. COF -6%. SC -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM
  • YGE

    Yingli Green +9% as some banks agree to modify loan payments

    • Yingli Green Energy (YGE +8.7%) remains sharply higher after saying it renegotiated interest rates and maturity dates on its credit lines with some of its banks, two months after it defaulted on 1.76B yuan ($267M) in debts.
    • In an earnings conference call, CFO Yiyu Wang did not identify the lenders, saying only that they applied to both short-term and long-term facilities; he said the rate reductions are "slight" but that the move would significantly lower the company's financial burden.
    • YGE also reported better than expected Q1 earnings; gross margin was 20% vs. 11.8% in Q4 2015 and 14.1% in the year-ago quarter, Q1 PV module shipments totaled 508.1 MW vs. 504.5 MW in Q4, and the company forecasts Q2 PV module shipments of 580-620 MW.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: LBIX-OLD +57%. OTC:BSPM +40%. EXAS +18%. LPTN +13%. VHC +16%. SGY +15%. OTC:CNXR +14%. VG +11%. AEMD +10%. OTC:COYN +10%.
    • Losers: INFI -70%. DRAM -28%. KMPH -26%. RVNC -22%. OTC:GBIM -20%. OTC:MDVX -17%. IMGN -17%. SYF -14%. INNL -13%. PQ -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM | 7 Comments
  • EMES

    Emerge Energy, Hi-Crush Partners get target price hikes at Wunderlich

    • Emerge Energy Services (EMES -5%) extends yesterday's pullback after shares more than doubled since the beginning of the month, but today's results are mixed for its frac sand peers.
    • Wunderlich raises its price target for EMES to $9 from $4, saying investors are growing more comfortable with the stabilization and a potential recovery in the space; with the large number of drilled uncompleted wells in the U.S., the firm believes it makes sense that completion and sand companies would be the first incremental beneficiaries of an uptick in activity, but adds the initial upticks still have not been noticed by EMES or in the field (Briefing.com).
    • The firm also raises its price target for Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP -0.6%) to $11 from $6, believing the recent equity raise made sense as it focuses on debt reduction and improving its financial position both for the downturn and an eventual recovery.
    • Also: SLCA -0.7%, FMSA +2.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 1 Comment
  • SKUL

    Skullcandy rises again after signing NDA with founder

    • A week after Skullcandy (SKUL +3%) founder Rick Alden disclosed he wants to take the headphone maker private, Alden has filed a 13D containing a letter from Skullcandy regarding a confidentiality agreement between the company and Alden (and his associates).
    • Alden's Ptarmagin, LLC owns 12.7% of Skullcandy, and Alden personally owns another 2.7%. Shares are up 14% since last week's disclosure.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 10 Comments
  • PBR

    Bloomberg: Petrobras’ Japan unit sale drawing strong interest

    • Petrobras' (PBR -3%) sale of its Japanese unit on Okinawa is drawing interest from at least seven companies, including JX Holdings and TonenGeneral Sekiyu, Bloomberg reports.
    • PBR bought an 87.5% in the Japanese company from TonenGeneral for 5.5B yen in April 2008, followed by a purchase of the remaining 12.5% stake from Sumitomo in 2010, but now seek to join Exxon and Shell in exiting Japan, where demand for oil products is forecast to fall more than 8% in the next five years.
    • PBR shut a 100K bbl/day refinery on Okinawa operated by Nansei Sekiyu last year as part of its plan to withdraw from Japan.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • SYF

    Synchrony Financial defended after credit warning

    • In conjunction with CFO Brian Doubles' appearance at a conference this morning, the company said it expects a 20-30 basis point increase in net charge off rates over the next year.
    • BTIG's Mark Palmer notes Doubles says Synchrony (SYF -14.3%) continues to see the credit environment as "benign," though management anticipates "softening" in customers' ability to pay off balances. Palmer also says credit metrics currently are at unusually low (good) levels, and "normalization" should be expected at this point in the cycle.
    • There's also a positive catalyst on the horizon in the CCAR results, at which Palmer expects the initiation of buybacks and a dividend.
    • He reiterates his Buy rating, with $42 price target (60% upside) based off of 12.5x 2018 estimated EPS of $3.33.
    • Discover (DFS -3.1%), Capital One (COF -6%), American Express (AXP -3.9%), OneMain Holdings (OMF -7.3%), Santander Consumer (SC -5.5%), Ally Financial (ALLY -2.9%)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:20 PM | 7 Comments

  • Consumer Goods - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: LBIX-OLD +53%. MPAA +6%. FORD +6%.
    • Losers: NAV -16%. WATT -11%. WNC -10%. RDEN -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM | 7 Comments
  • AOBC

    Gun rally begins to fade

    • Smith & Wesson (SWHC -6.3%) and Sturm Ruger (RGR -4.2%) are both sharply lower today as the volatile trading on the two guns stocks continues.
    • Investment firms have stayed away from issuing any ratings revisions since the mass shooting in Orlando. Many gun shop owners interviewed by the media have reported increased demand over the last few days.
    • Previously: Firearm makers' shares extend gains (June 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:48 AM | 28 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: OTC:CNXR +11%. AKAO +10%. AEMD +10%. EVAR +8%. AEGR +6%.
    • Losers: INFI -70%. KMPH -26%. RVNC -23%. OTC:GBIM -16%. IMGN -14%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • NRP

    Natural Resource to sell Williston Basin non-operated assets for $116M

    • Natural Resource Partners (NRP +1.9%) agrees to sell all of its Williston Basin non-operated oil and gas working interest assets for $116M to Lime Rock Resources.
    • NRP says the sale of the assets represents the company's exit from the non-operated oil and gas working interest business.
    • NRP says it will use the proceeds to pay off the $75M revolving credit facility and further its ongoing deleveraging strategy.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:36 AM | 10 Comments
  • RBBN

    Sonus dives as CFO Greenquist departs; guidance affirmed

    • Mark Greenquist, Sonus' (SONS -10.6%) CFO since Nov. 2013, has resigned to "take a similar role at a leading e-commerce platform company." Financial planning/analysis VP Susan Villare will serve as interim CFO while Sonus looks for a successor.
    • Sonus has affirmed its Q2 and 2016 revenue/EPS guidance. Shares have nonetheless fallen sharply.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:22 AM
  • TALO

    Stone Energy to make $29M in bond interest payments

    • Stone Energy (SGY +27.2%) surges higher at the open after disclosing that it will make the $29M interest payment on senior notes due 2022 that had been due on May 15, and thus will be in compliance with its lender obligations.
    • SGY also says it made the second borrowing base deficiency payment of $29.2M related to its amended credit agreement.
    • SGY says it continues to assess its restructuring alternatives.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM | 31 Comments
  • CHMA

    Chiasma cuts third of workforce on diminished outlook for Mycapssa; shares off 3%

    • Nano cap Chiasma (CHMA -2.9%) eases on light volume in response to its announcement that it will cut its workforce 33%, including almost all of its commercial staff, in order to extend its cash runway as it faces a much longer approval path for lead product candidate Mycapssa (octreotide) for the treatment of adults with acromegaly. Its decision was prompted by feedback from the FDA during a recent End-of-Review meeting reiterating the need for additional studies to demonstrate efficacy.
    • The company will record $1.4M - 1.6M in severance-related charges this quarter related to the downsizing as well as $0.3M - 0.4M in non-cash restructuring charges related to previously capitalized commercial software. As of March 31, its quick assets totaled $134.3M.
    • The Phase 3 MPOWERED trial supporting a Marketing Authorization Application (MAA) in Europe will proceed.
    • Previously: FDA rejects Chiasma's Mycapssa NDA (April 16)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:06 AM
  • COF

    Credit card players mull Synchrony warning

    • Synchrony Financial is down more than 8% after warning of an increase in charge-off rates over the next year.
    • Capital One (COF -2.8%), Discover (DFS -1.1%), American Express (AXP -1.6%).
    • Releasing its monthly statistics, Discover says its net principal charge-off rate in May was 2.4%, down 10 basis points from April, but up from the cycle low of 1.9% from last July. The delinquency over the last 30 days was 1.6%, flat from April and from last summer.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:59 AM | 4 Comments
  • SYF

    Synchrony Financial tumbles after loan-loss warning

    • Noting current historically low levels of loss rates, the company says it expects a 20-30 basis point increase in its net charge-off rates over the next year, and thus anticipates higher reserve builds starting this quarter.
    • Loan losses as a percent of loan receivables is likely to increase 20-30 bps this quarter from Q1.
    • SYF -8.6%
     
     
     
     
    | 9:54 AM | 8 Comments
  • VSTO

    Vista on the move

    • Vista Outdoor (NYSE:VSTO) is also getting a boost from the gun maker stock rally.
    • The company, which owns Savage Arms and Federal Premium Ammunition, is up 6% in premarket action.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:28 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:15 am

    • Gainers: YGE +21%. GBSN +16%. AKAO +7%.
    • Losers: INFI -68%. RVNC -26%. WGP -10%. DRAM -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:19 AM | 3 Comments
  • GBSN

    Great Basin nabs new patent covering AMPED technology; shares up 11% premarket

    • Nano cap Great Basin Scientific (NASDAQ:GBSN) jumps 11% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement that the USPTO has issued U.S. Patent No. 9,359,637 covering systems and methods of amplification of AMPED, the technology underpinning the company's proprietary detection chip which provides a visible result when the target of interest is present.
    • AMPED is highly sensitive and specific and can detect small amounts of a pathogen without requiring amplification by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Its value proposition is PCR-like sensitivity at a much lower cost and faster turnaround time.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM | 3 Comments
  • TSCO

    Guggenheim sees big run for Tractor Supply

    • Tractor Supply (NASDAQ:TSCO) is initiated by Guggenheim with a Buy rating.
    • Guggenheim's price target of $110 implies upside potential of 21% on the retailer which targets rural communities.
    • TSCO +0.46% premarket to $91.69.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM
  • SAEX

    SAExploration enters restructuring support deal, gets $30M in financing

    • SAExploration (NASDAQ:SAEX) -34.8% premarket after announcing it is entering into a new restructuring agreement with major holders of its senior secured notes due 2019.
    • SAEX says the restructuring includes an agreement to fund up to $30M in new capital to fund expected cash needs until the company can monetize its tax credit-related account receivables; the company agrees to issue the supporting bondholders common shares equal to 28.2% of the outstanding amount.
    • SAEX says the agreement will enhance its liquidity, provide financial flexibility, realign its balance sheet, and position the company for long-term growth.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:55 AM
  • NAV

    Navistar in decline after Stifel cut

    • Navistar (NYSE:NAV) slides in early trading after Stifel Nicolaus downgrades the stock to Sell.
    • Stifel issues a lowly price target of $10 on a dour view of Navistar.
    • "We believe Navistar may struggle to meet analysts’ estimates given our outlook for a multi-year period of declining heavy and medium duty truck production, which could impair the company’s ability to regain lost market share in a period of excess industry capacity," reads the note from analyst Michael Baudendiste.
    • NAV -3.95% premarket to $12.63.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:54 AM
  • WGP

    Western Gas Equity Partners in 12.5M-unit LP offering

    • Western Gas Equity Partners (NYSE:WGP) -9.3% premarket after announcing that limited partner and Anadarko Petroleum subsidiary Western Gas Resources priced a public offering of 12.5M common units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 1.875M units.
    • Western Gas Resources expects to receive ~$481M in gross proceeds from the offering; WGP is not selling any units in the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:40 AM
  • AOBC

    Firearm makers' shares extend gains

    • Gun stocks got a big boost yesterday in the wake of the mass shooting in Orlando.
    • Smith & Wesson ended the day almost 7% higher, while Sturm Ruger closed the trading session up 8.6%.
    • The two stocks are now looking to head higher: SWHC +2.7%; RGR +1% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:17 AM | 11 Comments
  • MESO

    Mesoblast slumps 36% premarket after Teva backs out of MPC-150-IM development

    • Thinly traded micro cap Mesoblast Limited (NASDAQ:MESO) is down 36% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement that development partner Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (NYSE:TEVA) has returned the rights to MPC-150-IM for the treatment of chronic heart failure to Mesoblast. Some analysts had speculated that Teva would back out of the collaboration because it was outside of its core business.
    • A 600-subject Phase 3 clinical trial assessing MPC-150-IM in heart failure is ongoing, with 40% of the enrollment target achieved.
    • MPC-150-IM is an "off the shelf" cell therapy based on mesenchymal lineage adult stem cells.
    • Update: On July 1, the company updated investors on the heart failure study saying top-line data on the primary endpoint is expected in Q1 2017. The anticipated costs to this interim analysis will be ~$13M, well below its existing cash balance of $80M. Its quick assets will be adequate to fund operations for 12-15 months and allow for the inclusion of programs in degenerative disc disease, graft-versus-host disease and biologic-refractory rheumatoid arthritis. A fully discretionary equity facility of up to $90M ($A120M) over 36 months has been established to provide additional liquidity if needed.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:16 AM | 2 Comments
  • INFI

    Infinity Pharma's lead product candidate duvelisib underwhelms in mid-stage lymphoma study; workforce cut 21%; shares off 67% premarket

    • Micro cap Infinity Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:INFI) is down 67% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement that will close down its discovery research organization and lay off 46 employees (21% of its workforce) prompted by less-than-expected results in a mid-stage study assessing lead product candidate duvelisib for the treatment of refractory indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (iNHL), a slow-growing blood cancer. In addition, the company and development partner AbbVie (NYSE:ABBV) have agreed to pause AbbVie's Phase 1b/2 trial evaluating the combination of duvelisib and venetoclax while Infinity evaluates its options with duvelisib.
    • The Phase 2 clinical trial, DYNAMO, assessed duvelisib as monotherapy in 129 patients with follicular lymphoma (n=83), small lymphocytic lymphoma (n=28) or marginal zone lymphoma (n=18) whose disease progressed or did not respond to treatment with Biogen's (NASDAQ:BIIB) Rituxan (rituximab) and either chemotherapy or radiotherapy. The primary endpoint was overall response rate (ORR).
    • Results showed an ORR of 46%, all partial responders and below expectations. The ORR in the three lymphoma types listed above were 41%, 68% and 33%, respectively. The data will be submitted to presentation at a future medical conference.
    • The most common serious adverse events (Grade 3 or higher) were neutropenia (low neutrophils) (28%), diarrhea (15%), thrombocytopenia (low blood platelets) (13%) and anemia (12%). 20% of participants experienced an infection of least Grade 3 (serious).
    • CEO Adelene Perkins says, "While DYNAMO met its primary endpoint, we hoped that treatment with duvelisib as monotherapy would have provided a larger clinical benefit....We plan to seek feedback from the FDA to determine our next steps with respect to duvelisib in iNHL."
    • Duvelisib is an investigational inhibitor of Class 1 phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-delta and PI3K-gamma being jointly developed by Infinity and AbbVie. The PI3K pathway plays a key role in regulating the growth and survival of certain blood cancers. Inhibiting PI3K-delta and PI3K-gamma signaling blocks the growth and survival of tumor cells.
    • Infinity will release updated guidance after all these activities have been completed. Management will host a conference call at 8:30 am to discuss the situation.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:54 AM
  • BCS

    Bank of England pumps cash into banking system ahead of Brexit vote

    • The Bank of England is offering the country's lenders extra liquidity to help them get through any volatility surrounding next week's Brexit vote. Banks today tapped the central bank for £2.46 of that cash.
    • While that amount at repo auctions isn't unusual (they're held every month), the BoE is offering an extra three auctions in June - two before the vote and one after.
    • The stock prices of British banks have been under heavy pressure ahead of the vote, and most are lower again today. In London trade: Barclays (NYSE:BCS) -2.9%, RBS -1.7%, Lloyds (NYSE:LYG) -1.9%, HSBC -1.15%.
    • The FTSE 100 is down 1.2%, and the pound (NYSEARCA:FXB) is off 1% vs. the dollar.
    • ETFs: FXB, EWU, OTC:GBB, EWUS, FKU, DXPS, DBUK, QGBR, HEWU
     
     
     
     
    | 7:42 AM | 8 Comments
  • ZBH

    Zimmer Biomet announces pricing of secondary offering; shares off 3% premarket

    • Zimmer Biomet (ZBH -0.8%) announces the pricing of the previously announced underwritten secondary offering of 11,116,533 shares of its common stock by certain of its stockholders, consisting of affiliates of KKR, Goldman Sachs and TPG. The shares are being sold at $115.85 per share. The selling stockholders will receive all of the proceeds of the offering.
    • Closing date is June 16.
    • Shares are down 3% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:41 AM
  • YGE

    Yingli Green Energy beats by $0.12, beats on revenue

    • Yingli Green Energy (NYSE:YGE): Q1 EPS of $0.06 beats by $0.12.
    • Revenue of $364.6M (-22.2% Y/Y) beats by $10.62M.
    • Shares +9.1% PM.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:38 AM | 3 Comments
